bboxes.raw_text:
NEW YORK = Roy Wilkins,
executive secretary Of the
National ASS ociation for the Ad-
vancement of Colored People, has
announced the assignment Of Miss
Althea T. L. Simmons as coordin-
ator of the associations nation
wide voter registration drive.


Miss Simmons, an NAACP field
secretary for the southern and
southwest areas of the West c cast
region, was transferred to the
association national office here
to devote full time to the regis
tration drive until the election in
November.


A longtime NAACP member
and volunteer worker, Miss Sim
mons was executive secretary Of

the Texas State Conference Of
NAACP branches, lo5o-60, also
served as chairman Of the exc
cutive committee Of the Dallas
NAACP Branch. She joined the
national staff in 1861 when she
was appointed field secretary
working out the NAACP sub
regional office in Los Angeles.


A former college teacher and
newspaperwoman, Miss Simmons
was graduated from Southern
University in Baton Rouge. La,
and holds an MS. degree from
the University ofIllinois, an LIB
from the Howard University Scool
of Law, and diploma in por-
traiture from the New York In
stitute of Photography.
Miss Simmons is Promoted By NAACP

For the past four years this has scholar
ships entering freshmen in city high schools The
encouraging because majority of the failed
during their first year. Many poor
poor grades.


These students chosen from their respective eighth grade
they according
scholastic and activity achievements.


AS the high school year begins that those students
who receive financial assistance from the Arizona Tribune
any other organization will earnestly stay school
and do their BEST


In discussions with other of groups who have
contributed funds for deserving scholars high school college
there that students scholarships
and take their school responsibilities lightly.


Far few Negroes receive scholarships and the individuals
who receive them should their BEST Those students who do
win scholarships should likewise work hard their
merit and learn much they

ANO REVIEWS


Edward Banks
Edward Banks
Scholarships Wasted

The Worlds Fair Corporation
itself built only seven of the $50
Fair pavilions: the us. Post Of
fee, the administration building,
the press building, the Worlds
Fair Pavilion and the security,
entrance and maintenance build.
ings. All other structures at the
Fair were built by exhibitors.
BUILT BY EXHIBITORS

Dance proceeds will be given
the Maryvale Lions Sight
Conservation and Community
Betterment Fund.


Live entertainment at the dance
will include three different bands
and Hollywood recording stars,
among them the 5lendelis.

KRUx Sponsors Charity
Back To School Dance

Valley teen-agers are invited
to a charity "Back to School
Blast" spoons ored by KRUX radio
station, Sum-, Sept. E, S-l2 pm.
in the Exhibition Building at the
Arizona State Playground, 10Th
Avenue and Mcdowell.

The efforts of the Mississippi Freedom
Party at the Democratic National COnUen-
tiOn in Atlantic City is a major step in the
new look in politics. The emphasis ON
complete citizenship in the United States
must be brought to its full measure at the
ballot box and within the polling booths.


Negroes in many states are derehct
in their CHIC duties. They often ignore 5f
the political world which surrounds them. +
Unfortunately Negro UoteY registrations
haze not only Jagged in the South, but eia
Negroes haze failed to register and cote = 8
in many states where no barriers haze d1ia
been placed. ~


Great interest is focused on the national j,
political scene at the expense Of local con-.
tests. This year in our oMm state an 0tn'oS-
bheTe Of ina ctivity is noticed as the last
fen weeks approach before the primary
elections.


No person should be content to we INT
legts lattve district or county district and
be unawave of the candidates or issues IN
UOlUed


There should be more action on the local
leuel in politics and all persons regardless
of race, creed, color or national origin
should pledge themselves to making better
g0Ue 17anaent a reality.


Miss Simmons is Promoted By NAAcP
new LOOK

General Of these United States Of
America, produced an amaz-
ing medical report. He and his
associates prepared and released
a report which most Of our In
habitants had already known. He
revealed to millions of United
Staters that cigarette smoking
was detrimental to the health
of the people.


The cry and the howl arose
from all sources before the re-
port was re- reSearched. The
cigarette manufacturers yelled
"foul." The tobacco growing
states produced dissenting views.
The smokers themselves turned
some deaf ears; few responded
and took the oath to abstain from
the deadly leaf.


Claims and counterclaims
against and In favor Of the In
nocent looking dried weed
swathed in white paper ragged.
Advertisers we're instructed that
the federal government would
henceforth regulate cigarette ad-
vertising. Packs ofsmokes we're
to contain statements about them
being dangerous to ones health.
Some persons suggested that each
package should have skull and
crossbones on the label.


Daily millions of buffers tried
to satiate the desire for smoke.
Leading cigarette manufacturers
noted declines in their sales and
sales of their stocks diminished.
After less than three months the
big scare is off. More smokers
have withstood the truth and again
putting is back to its regular
schedule.


Cigarettes are now produced
with more filter, more menthol,
more mint, more colorful paper
wrappings and more sizes; how
ever, the one real thing which
remains unchanged is that
cigarette smoking is not healthy.


Advertising specialists make
smoking appeal to even the non
smokers. Would you believe 1T
Great athletes smoke while
scaling mountains or after SWIM
ming the English Channel. Others
must grab a flag or two after
dinner or while preparing to pro-
pose.


One bright advertiser took ad-
vantage Of the names offspring
and "tempe." These new
sounding names give cigarettes a
new sound. saw one package
labeled Frappe. This gives the
sound Of a delicious drink.


Free cigarettes have been
halted for distribution at colleges
and some hospitals. One group
of hospital workers in an eastern
city rebelled when the vending
machines we're removed.


Being nonsmoker, Ihave only
one law which I would like to have
passed No Smoking in stores,
buses, trains and airplanes.


The aroma Of cigar smoke is no
more enjoyable than cigarette
smoking. If cigarettes 60 out of
use cigars will be the next
on the list. Our women cold be
fashionable putting on corn cob
pipes think there would be
new market opening for miniature
corn cobs of every color to match
miladys dress.


Efforts to halt smoking have
gone through the usual stages,
perhaps, statement attributed to
VIC. Fields Is truer now more
than ever. The bulb nose comic
repeatedly said that everything
he liked was either immoral, IL
local or- fafteninO

NUMBER THREE


Two weeks ago the list of candidates mho
passed the bar examinations Of the state was
published. Rubin SalteY a 28 year old Negro,
became the first of his race to practice LAM
in Tucson.


Congratulations to NM. SaHeY, 1Uh0 told re-
borteys that he wants to Practice not only
discrimination cases, but all kinds of LAM.
We wish him great success.


For several gears Negro applicants haze
unsuccess tully sat for the state bar exanain-
atoms. RumOYs of yu cial dis elimination or
political influence haze been giUen as the
reasons for their failures. There is little to
justify such claims.


The story of the first Negro attorney ab-
bearing in the daily paper contained a glar1mg
error. mentioned that there as only one
other Negro attorney IN Arizona a Ted
LaYRin of Phoenix. This is false, there are
tho other Negro attorneys bructicing in
Phoenix Hayzel Daniels and Carl SteWuT.
injuries haze shoam that Ted LaYkin is not
listed in the area.


These three haze demonstrated their ability
to pass the state bar requirements and they
are proud to be called attorneys, not Negro
attorneys.


Remember TO Vote Sept. 9th
